summary.text: Net force causes momentum change: Δp = F_net Δt. Momentum p = mv. Force is rate of momentum change.

importance.text: Unifies Newton's laws. Force doesn't cause motion—it causes momentum change. More fundamental than F = ma.

explanations.text: Because momentum is what's conserved in interactions. Force transfers momentum between objects.
Newton's Second Law is really F = dp/dt. For constant mass, this becomes F = ma, but the momentum form is more general.
Space translation symmetry requires momentum conservation. Force breaks this symmetry locally, creating momentum flow.

questions.text: A 1500 kg car travels at 20 m/s. What is its momentum?

options.explanation: This divides mass by velocity. Momentum multiplies them: p = mv.
This adds mass and velocity. Momentum multiplies them.
Correct. p = mv = 1500 × 20 = 30,000 kg⋅m/s.
Right magnitude, wrong units. Momentum uses kg⋅m/s, not N.

feedback.correct: Right. p = mv gives the momentum.
feedback.incorrect: Momentum = mass × velocity.

questions.text: A 0.15 kg baseball changes velocity from 20 m/s to -15 m/s. What impulse was applied?

options.explanation: This only considers final momentum. Impulse = change in momentum.
This is initial momentum. Need the change: Δp = p_final - p_initial.
Correct. Δp = m(v_f - v_i) = 0.15(-15 - 20) = 0.15(-35) = -5.3 N⋅s. Magnitude is 5.3 N⋅s.
You forgot the mass. Impulse = mass × change in velocity.

feedback.correct: You handled the direction reversal correctly.
feedback.incorrect: Impulse = change in momentum = m(v_final - v_initial).

questions.text: A constant 50 N force acts for 0.20 s on a 2.0 kg object initially at rest. What is the final velocity?

options.explanation: This is the impulse value. Remember to divide by mass for velocity change.
Check calculation: Impulse = 10 N⋅s, so Δv = 10/2.0 = 5.0 m/s.
This multiplies instead of dividing. Use FΔt = mΔv to find Δv.

feedback.correct: You used the impulse-momentum theorem correctly.
feedback.incorrect: Use FΔt = mΔv. Find impulse first, then divide by mass.
feedback.explanation: Impulse = 50 × 0.20 = 10 N⋅s. From rest: 10 = 2.0 × v, so v = 5.0 m/s.

questions.text: Which statement about force and momentum is most fundamental?

options.explanation: This is F = ma, which is a special case of the more general momentum relationship.

options.text: Force is the rate of momentum change
options.explanation: Correct. F = dp/dt is Newton's original formulation and most general form.
Force doesn't cause motion—objects can move with zero force. Force changes motion.
This assumes constant mass. The momentum form F = dp/dt is more general.

feedback.correct: You understand the fundamental nature of force.
feedback.incorrect: Force is fundamentally the rate of change of momentum: F = dp/dt.
feedback.explanation: Newton's Second Law in its most general form is F = dp/dt, not F = ma.

questions.text: On a force-time graph, what does the area under the curve represent?

options.explanation: Work is force × displacement, not force × time.
Power is energy per time, not related to force-time area.
Correct. Impulse = ∫F dt, which is the area under the force-time curve.
Kinetic energy change relates to work (force × displacement), not impulse.

feedback.correct: You understand the geometric meaning of impulse.
feedback.incorrect: Area under force-time curve gives impulse = change in momentum.
feedback.explanation: Impulse = ∫F dt, which geometrically is the area under the F-t graph.

questions.text: The units of momentum are equivalent to:

options.explanation: Correct. Since F = dp/dt, then dp = F dt, so momentum has units N⋅s.
These are units of work or torque, not momentum.
These are units of force (N), not momentum.
These are units of action (angular momentum × time), not linear momentum.

feedback.correct: You know the equivalent units for momentum.
feedback.incorrect: Momentum = mass × velocity = kg⋅m/s = N⋅s.
feedback.explanation: Since F = dp/dt, then p = ∫F dt, so momentum has units N⋅s.

questions.text: For a rocket burning fuel, why is F = dp/dt more useful than F = ma?

options.explanation: Rockets do accelerate. The issue is that their mass changes.
Correct. F = ma assumes constant mass. F = dp/dt handles changing mass: F = m(dv/dt) + v(dm/dt).
High velocity doesn't invalidate F = ma. The changing mass does.
Changing gravity affects force, but doesn't make F = ma invalid. Mass change does.

feedback.correct: You understand when the momentum form is essential.
feedback.incorrect: F = dp/dt accounts for changing mass: F = d(mv)/dt = m(dv/dt) + v(dm/dt).
feedback.explanation: When mass changes, F = ma fails. Use F = dp/dt = m(dv/dt) + v(dm/dt).

questions.text: In an isolated system, total momentum is conserved because:

options.explanation: This describes Newton's Third Law, but doesn't explain why momentum is conserved.
Correct. Since F_net = dp/dt, if F_net = 0, then dp/dt = 0, so momentum is constant.
Energy conservation is separate from momentum conservation.
Mass conservation doesn't guarantee momentum conservation without considering velocities.

feedback.correct: You understand the connection between force and momentum conservation.
feedback.incorrect: If net external force is zero, then dp/dt = 0, so momentum is conserved.
feedback.explanation: F_net = dp_total/dt. If F_net = 0, then dp_total/dt = 0, so p_total = constant.

questions.text: A large force for 0.10 s gives the same impulse as a small force for 1.0 s. The forces are related by:

options.explanation: If times differ, forces must differ to give equal impulse.
Correct. For equal impulse: F_large × 0.10 = F_small × 1.0, so F_large = 10 × F_small.
This would make the large force smaller than the small force.
This overcounts the time ratio. Check: 0.10/1.0 = 0.10, so factor is 10.

feedback.correct: You understand the trade-off between force and time in impulse.
feedback.incorrect: Equal impulse means F₁t₁ = F₂t₂, so F₁/F₂ = t₂/t₁.
feedback.explanation: F_large × 0.10 = F_small × 1.0 gives F_large = 10 × F_small.

questions.text: A 3.0 kg object moving at 8.0 m/s east collides with a 2.0 kg object at rest. After collision, the 3.0 kg object moves at 2.0 m/s east. Find the velocity of the 2.0 kg object.

steps.text: Apply conservation of momentum: p_initial = p_final

summary.text: Weight is gravitational force: F_g = mg, where g = 9.8 N/kg near Earth's surface. Acts at center of mass.

importance.text: Distinguishes mass (intrinsic property) from weight (force). Weight varies with location; mass doesn't.

explanations.text: Because gravity is a field. Every mass experiences force in Earth's gravitational field.
Mass warps spacetime. Other masses follow geodesics in this curved spacetime, appearing as force.
Einstein's equivalence principle: gravitational and inertial mass are identical. Gravity isn't a force—it's geometry.

questions.text: A 5.0 kg object near Earth's surface has weight:

options.explanation: This ignores gravitational field strength. Weight = mg, not just m.
This is just g. Weight = mass × gravitational field strength.
Correct. F_gravity = mg = 5.0 × 9.8 = 49 N downward.
Right magnitude, wrong units. Force is measured in Newtons, not kilograms.

feedback.correct: Weight equals mass times gravitational field strength.
feedback.incorrect: Weight = mg where g = 9.8 N/kg near Earth's surface.
feedback.explanation: F_gravity = mg = 5.0 kg × 9.8 N/kg = 49 N downward.

questions.text: An astronaut with mass 70 kg on Earth travels to the Moon where g = 1.6 N/kg. What changes?

options.explanation: Mass is intrinsic and doesn't change with location.
Correct. Mass = 70 kg everywhere. Weight = mg = 70 × 1.6 = 112 N on Moon.
Mass is intrinsic property, independent of gravitational field.

options.text: Both mass and weight stay same
options.explanation: Weight depends on gravitational field strength, which differs on Moon.

feedback.correct: You understand the distinction between mass and weight.
feedback.incorrect: Mass is intrinsic; weight = mg depends on local gravitational field.
feedback.explanation: Mass = 70 kg (constant). Weight on Moon = 70 × 1.6 = 112 N vs 686 N on Earth.

questions.text: Why model gravitational force as acting at the center of mass?

options.explanation: Center of mass isn't necessarily the heaviest point—it's the balance point.
Correct. For translational motion, all gravitational forces on parts sum to mg at center of mass.
Gravitational field is nearly uniform over small objects, so strength is similar everywhere.
Center of mass and geometric center are only the same for uniform density objects.

feedback.correct: You understand why we use center of mass for force analysis.
feedback.incorrect: Center of mass is where we can model the total gravitational force as acting.
feedback.explanation: All gravitational forces on object parts combine into single force mg at center of mass.

questions.text: Gravitational field strength g has units N/kg, which is equivalent to:

options.explanation: These are momentum units, not acceleration units.
Correct. Since F = mg and F = ma, then mg = ma, so g = a. Units: N/kg = (kg⋅m/s²)/kg = m/s².
These are energy or torque units, not field strength units.
These are density units, not gravitational field units.

feedback.correct: You understand that gravitational field strength equals acceleration.
feedback.incorrect: g is both field strength (N/kg) and acceleration (m/s²).
feedback.explanation: N/kg = (kg⋅m/s²)/kg = m/s². Gravitational field strength = gravitational acceleration.

questions.text: A person weighs 700 N at sea level. At altitude where g = 9.7 N/kg, they weigh:

options.explanation: Weight changes with gravitational field strength.
Correct. Mass = 700/9.8 = 71.4 kg. New weight = 71.4 × 9.7 = 693 N.
This assumes g increased, but 9.7 < 9.8.

questions.text: A 60 kg person in an elevator accelerating upward at 2.0 m/s² experiences apparent weight:

options.explanation: This subtracts ma from mg. For upward acceleration, normal force increases.
This is just ma. Apparent weight = mg + ma for upward acceleration.
This applies downward acceleration formula. Check: upward acceleration increases apparent weight.

questions.text: During free fall, an object's weight is:

options.explanation: Weight (mg) still exists. Apparent weight (normal force) is zero.
Gravitational force (weight) doesn't change during free fall.

questions.text: On planet X where g = 15 N/kg, a 40 kg astronaut weighs:

questions.text: The direction of gravitational force on an object is always:

options.explanation: Only true on Earth's surface. 'Downward' has no meaning in space.

concepts.title: Newton's Laws and Force Vectors
concepts.equation: F_net = ma, F_on A by B = -F_on B by A

summary.text: Forces are vectors with magnitude and direction. Newton's laws: (1) inertia, (2) F_net = ma, (3) action-reaction pairs.

importance.text: Foundation of classical mechanics. Forces always come in pairs. Net force determines acceleration, not motion.

explanations.text: Because forces have direction—push which way matters. Interactions are mutual—no force acts alone.
Conservation laws require it. Momentum conservation demands action-reaction pairs. Symmetry of space requires vector nature.
Noether's theorem: translation symmetry gives momentum conservation, which requires Newton's Third Law. Isotropy requires vector forces.

questions.text: Newton's First Law states that an object at rest or in uniform motion will:

options.text: Eventually slow down due to friction
options.explanation: This assumes friction exists. First Law applies when net force is zero.

options.text: Continue in that state unless acted upon by a net force
options.explanation: Correct. This is the law of inertia—objects resist changes in motion.

options.text: Accelerate in the direction of motion
options.explanation: Uniform motion means constant velocity, so no acceleration.
Objects in motion stay in motion unless a net force acts on them.

feedback.correct: You understand the principle of inertia.
feedback.incorrect: First Law: objects maintain their state of motion unless net force acts.
feedback.explanation: Inertia means objects resist changes in motion—they continue as they are.

questions.text: A 10 kg object experiences forces of 30 N east and 20 N west. Its acceleration is:

options.explanation: Correct. Net force = 30 - 20 = 10 N east. a = F/m = 10/10 = 1.0 m/s² east.
This uses total force instead of net force. Net force = 30 - 20 = 10 N.
Check net force calculation. Opposing forces subtract: 30 - 20 = 10 N.
The forces don't balance. Net force = 10 N east, so acceleration exists.

feedback.correct: You found net force first, then applied F = ma.
feedback.incorrect: Find net force first: 30 N - 20 N = 10 N east.
feedback.explanation: Net F = 10 N east, so a = F/m = 10/10 = 1.0 m/s² east.

questions.text: When you push a wall with 100 N, the wall pushes back with:

options.explanation: All forces come in action-reaction pairs. The wall must push back.
Newton's Third Law: action and reaction forces are always equal in magnitude.
Correct. Newton's Third Law: F_on wall by you = -F_on you by wall. Equal magnitudes.
Action-reaction pairs have equal magnitudes. The wall can't push harder than you push it.

feedback.correct: You understand Newton's Third Law.
feedback.incorrect: Action and reaction forces are always equal in magnitude and opposite in direction.
feedback.explanation: Newton's Third Law: for every action, there's an equal and opposite reaction.

questions.text: Two forces act on an object: 40 N north and 30 N east. The magnitude of the net force is:

options.explanation: This subtracts the forces. Perpendicular forces add using Pythagorean theorem.
This adds magnitudes directly. For perpendicular forces, use vector addition.
Correct. For perpendicular forces: |F_net| = √(40² + 30²) = √(1600 + 900) = √2500 = 50 N.
This takes the average. Use Pythagorean theorem for perpendicular vectors.

feedback.correct: You correctly used vector addition for perpendicular forces.
feedback.incorrect: For perpendicular forces: |F_net| = √(F₁² + F₂²).

questions.text: A 50 N force at 37° above horizontal has horizontal component:

options.explanation: This uses sine instead of cosine. Horizontal component uses adjacent side.
This is the total force magnitude, not just the horizontal component.

feedback.correct: You correctly used cosine for the horizontal component.
feedback.incorrect: Horizontal component: F_x = F cos θ where θ is angle from horizontal.

questions.text: A book rests on a table. Which is NOT an action-reaction pair?

options.text: Book's weight and Earth's gravitational pull on book
options.explanation: These are the same force, not an action-reaction pair.

options.text: Normal force of table on book and normal force of book on table
options.explanation: These are action-reaction pairs—contact forces between book and table.

options.text: Earth pulls book down and book pulls Earth up
options.explanation: These are action-reaction pairs—gravitational forces are mutual.

options.text: Book's weight and normal force from table
options.explanation: Correct. These act on the same object (book) so cannot be action-reaction pairs.

feedback.correct: You understand that action-reaction pairs act on different objects.
feedback.incorrect: Action-reaction pairs act on different objects, not the same object.
feedback.explanation: Weight and normal force both act on the book, so they balance but aren't action-reaction pairs.

questions.text: If net force on an object is zero, the object:

options.explanation: Zero net force means zero acceleration, but object could be moving at constant velocity.

options.text: Must be moving at constant velocity
options.explanation: Object could be at rest (which is constant velocity of zero) or moving at constant non-zero velocity.
Correct. F_net = ma, so if F_net = 0, then a = 0.

options.text: Cannot have any forces acting on it
options.explanation: Zero net force means forces balance, not that no forces exist.

feedback.correct: You understand the relationship between net force and acceleration.
feedback.incorrect: F_net = ma. If F_net = 0, then a = 0 (but velocity can be anything constant).
feedback.explanation: Zero net force means zero acceleration—object maintains whatever velocity it has.

questions.text: Forces must be modeled as vectors because:

options.explanation: Force magnitude doesn't determine whether it's a vector. Direction is the key.

options.text: Forces have both magnitude and direction
options.explanation: Correct. Forces are vectors because they have both magnitude and direction of action.
Forces can be in any direction. The vector nature isn't about sign but about direction.
Units don't determine vector nature. Temperature has units but isn't a vector.

feedback.correct: Direction is essential for force—push which way.
feedback.incorrect: Vectors have both magnitude and direction.
feedback.explanation: Force without direction is meaningless. You must specify both how hard and which way.

questions.text: An object in equilibrium has:

options.explanation: Equilibrium means forces balance (net force = 0), not that no forces exist.
Correct. Equilibrium means ΣF = 0, so acceleration is zero.
Forces just need to sum to zero—they don't need equal magnitudes.
Equilibrium means zero acceleration, but velocity can be constant (including zero).

feedback.correct: You understand the condition for mechanical equilibrium.
feedback.incorrect: Equilibrium means net force = 0, so acceleration = 0.
feedback.explanation: Equilibrium: ΣF = 0, which gives a = 0 (constant velocity).

summary.text: Normal force acts perpendicular to surfaces. Friction opposes motion. Static friction: f ≤ μ_s N. Kinetic friction: f_k = μ_k N.

importance.text: Contact forces enable walking, braking, gripping. Friction both helps and hinders motion. Normal force distributes weight.

explanations.text: Because surfaces interact. Microscopic bumps and valleys create resistance. Normal force prevents penetration.
Electromagnetic forces between atoms. Contact is really very close approach where electron clouds repel strongly.
Pauli exclusion principle: electrons can't occupy same quantum state. This creates the impenetrability of matter.

questions.text: A 2.0 kg book rests on a horizontal table. The normal force from the table is:

options.explanation: Without normal force, the book would fall through the table.
This is just the mass. Normal force must balance the weight: mg.
Correct. Normal force balances weight: N = mg = 2.0 × 9.8 = 20 N upward.
Direction is wrong. Normal force opposes weight, so it points upward.

feedback.correct: Normal force balances the gravitational force.
feedback.incorrect: For equilibrium: normal force up = weight down = mg.
feedback.explanation: Book at rest means net force = 0. Normal force must equal weight = 20 N upward.

questions.text: Static friction force:

options.explanation: This is maximum static friction. Actual static friction equals applied force up to this limit.
Static friction prevents motion by opposing the applied force.

options.text: Equals the applied force (up to maximum)
options.explanation: Correct. Static friction adjusts to match applied force, preventing motion, up to μ_s N.
Static and kinetic friction are different. Static friction acts when there's no motion.

feedback.correct: Static friction 'fights back' to prevent motion.
feedback.incorrect: Static friction equals applied force until maximum is reached.
feedback.explanation: Static friction adjusts to balance applied force, preventing motion.

questions.text: For the same surfaces, static friction coefficient is usually:

options.explanation: Static friction is usually greater—it's harder to start motion than maintain it.
Coefficients are different because starting motion differs from maintaining motion.
Correct. μ_s > μ_k because surfaces interlock more when at rest.

questions.text: Kinetic friction always acts:

questions.text: You push a box against a vertical wall with 200 N horizontal force. The normal force from the wall is:

options.explanation: The wall must push back to prevent the box from penetrating the wall.
